Item_Details.Item_Response: Most people find this internet encyclopidia to be very accurate. According to Dan Fletcher Wikipedia only makes about 3.86 mistakes per article.(A Brief History Of Wikipedia). However, because of the popularity and trust people put into this site many of those 3.86 mistakes are taken to be fact. Some of these "fake facts" make it to the public, even in the local news.(Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote).

Many of the sources explain that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. Source #4 is all about an Irish student posting a false quote on Maurice Jarre's Wikipedia page. In the second paragraph the writer says, "...flew straight on to dozens of U.S blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India." That shows, even professional researches believed that it was a real quote. So, ordinary people would definatley believe it because they don't know either way. In source #2 Dan Fletcher says, "...the English-language version of the controversial user-generated encylopedia..." Wikipedia isn't written by experts, it is written by regular people. So, if you didn't like some one and wanted to write something negative and biased, you could do that. That is why false information is spread quickly on the site.

"...he expected newspapers to avoid his quote because it had no link to a source-and even might trigger alarms as "too good to be true". But many blogs and several newspapers used the quotes at the start or finish of their obituaries."(Source #4) Our race has been getting lazier and lazier as every generation is born. We don't want to take that extra step; we're lazy."But the errors on the test last semester were the last straw." We all have to force us to double check if it starts to affect issues like our education. Everyone depended on a questionable search engine for the cost of their education.

Source No. 4 is a prime example of how misinformation can go viral and be accepted with no contest. By using Wikipedia as an outlet, Shane Fitzgerald posted a quote claiming to be from a recently deceased composer. Though the quote was not vulgar or disrespectful, it was made up. This made up quote, however, did make it to newspapers and blogs around the world. Source No. 5 also shows the spread of misinformation on Wikipedia with a group of college students that studied information that, again, was not crude or inappropriate, simply false.

Misinformation on wikipedia can happen but the wikipedia team is working hard to make sure there is no vulgar language or false information. Misinformation on wikipedia is likely to happen because anyone can request to put information on their website.

Although most information on Wikipedia may or may not be up to par, the information provided was created and edited by the users, not the professionals (Source #3). A test was also experimented when Shane Fitzgerald posted a poetic but fake quote on Wikipedia. He stated that he was testing how our globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was effecting the people and who accurate and accountable they believe the instant news is (Source #4). Another incident occured with a half dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class at Middlebury College, Vermont. Incorrrect information was posted on Wikipedia and the students used and sourced the false information for an exam (Source #5).

In Source #4, "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote", several newspapers ran a print with an eerily similar mistake, a farce quote designed to see how it would impact the media. Several newspapers had made this mistake and this evidences that Wikipedia has a major influence among popular media. In Source #5, "Wikipedia on academic hit list" the students had made similar mistakes on their exams becuase of a flaw in Wikipedia's information. This also supportts the previous statement because everyone had that same mistake meaning that Wikipedia misinformation spreads quikly.

Wikipedia is known to be a trusted source of information, but who is to say that every entry on wikipedia contains solid facts. In source #4, Shane Fitzgerald, an Irish student from Dublin University, conducted a test to see how fast blogs and entries were spread. He conducted his research by posting a poetic, but false, quote on Wikipedia. The qoute was supposably by Maurice Jarre and was posted on the French composer's page hours after his death on March 28. This quote flew straight into dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India. Administrators at wikipedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it from the site. A full month went by and nobody nodiced that the editorial was false. Because of the test results, Fitzgerald was one hundred percent convinced that if he hadn't come foward, the false quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something he made up. Source #5 also demonstrates that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. In Middlebury College, Vermont, half a dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class asserted on exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimaba Rebellion in 17th-Century Japan. Waters knew something was wrong. According to his knowledge the Jesuits were in "no position to aid a revolution, the few of them in Japan were hiding." Where was this misleading information comming from? Waters and other professors in the history department had begun noticing that about a year ago, students were citing wikipedia as a source in their papers. More misinformation spread and certain errors showed up on last semesters test. Those errors came from the information of wikipedia. Both these sources show how fast and easily misleading information can spread.

Wikipedia has entries that are posted with unclear information that can spread quickly. In source #2 it states that Wikipedia is created by users and not by traditional experts, this causes the entries to have simple mistakes that can confuse a reader and have them misunderstand the writers entry. In source #4 the story of a boy, by the name Fitzgerald, is told. It says that he, "posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia to test how our globalized, increasingly Internet- dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in our age of instant news." This phony quote was used in blogs and newspapers at the start and finish of their obituaries. This demonstrates unreliable monitoring by Wikipedia and that false information posted on Wikipedia does spread rapidly.

Information and rumors alike can spread very quickly in the world today. Due to the advancement of technology and instant messaging news travels very quickly. One instance of this happening is in Source #4 which tells of a Dublin university student who purposely spread untrue information on Wikipedia to see how fast the hoax would travel. The media spread it very quickly and most media once they reported it didn't take it back even after they knew it was a hoax. Source #1 also shows that 79% of all American adults age 18 and older use the internet. Its easy to see how news can spread so fast with the advanced technology we now have.

The misinformation that spread quickly throught wikipedia may have happened because the problems that had happened at the beginning. Source #2 states that "vandalism and lack of a fixed formual for determining what should and shouldn't be included" was one of the problems. The emerging community included a volunteer army of editors" as said in source #2. Which means that anybody could edit a wikipedia page if they wanted to. Another example of why misinformation that was posted on wikipedia could spread quickly is talked about in source #3. In source #3 it talks about how a huge fraud was made. It states that "fitzgerald psoted a poetic but phony quote on wikipedia" and "even though administrators at the free online encyclopeida quickly caught the quotes lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some from cutting and pasting it." Which shows that although wikipedia catches wrong information they don't catch it fast enough due to how popular wikipedia is.

Human beings are not perfect by nature. Wikipedia is run by people; therefore, is not perfect, regardless of how many times the editors review articles. This may happen because as shown in Source #4, someone may accidentally or intentionally publish false information onto the website. Though the editors of Wikipedia caught the mistake rather quickly in the circumstances that Source #4 was subjected to, it was not before it was printed for mass media consumption. Though a mea culpa was written and the mayhem was straightened out, had the student not come forward and confessed, many would have taken the false quote as truth. In a different case, things may not play out in the same way and mass media may publish the information as fact for longer periods of time. According to Source #3, Wikipedia is edited by anyone; therefore, is easily changed by people that are not professional. It is indeeed created by users, and must therefore be taken with skepticism, as a user can post a hoax that many others around the world can take as fact.

Source A shows a graph showing the growth of usage for wikipedia. So seeing that this many people use the website we can say that information even thought it may be incorrect can be used. In Source 5 it shows how students all over the world can get misinformation anywhere throught the website.

Wikipedia includes a great amount of misinformation. For example, a 2005 study by Nature found that Wikipedia's science entries came close to matching the Encyclopedia Britannica's in terms of accuracy--....with 3.86 mistakes per article for Wikipedia. (Source 2) The content's reliability should be met with some skepticism because it is in fact created by users and not traditional "experts." (Source #3) Wikipedia lacks accuracy because many people cannot be trusted where they are able to submit false information.
source 2 says that there was a lot of vandelism and a lack of fixed formulas source 3 says that it is created by the users of the website and not thetraditional "experts"

It is clear through reading a few of the sources that there are definite flaws in the way wikipedia is used and monitored. in source 4, a student uses a made up quote by a french composer to eperiment with how the world utilizes wikipedia. Although wikipedia may have caught the fraudulent quote submitted by the student, it was cut and pasted by multiple sources before wikipedia had the chance to remove it. This fake quote began circulating through newspapers and blogs like wildfire. Similarly, the Japanese history students in Vermont were all in fault of using the bad information they found on wikipedia while taking their exam, and it was evident throughout the class that none of them had caught the mistake and that they had all just assumed it to be true. This false information found on wikipedia has a way of circulating itself through student work, newspaper sites, and other academic projects that ends up making the authors look silly when someone else corrects their mistake.

Wikipedia administators cannot catch every fault that goes on the webpage which leads to misinformation. Media spreads quickly even if the information is wrong. For instance, Shane Fitzgerald made a up a quote saying it was by famous composer Maurice Jarre. The quote spread quickly by journalist and it was used in many articles even though Maurice never said that. The article says, " A full month went by nobody noticed the editorial fraud." (Source #4). Also, half a dozen students in a history class used Wikipedia as their source for information on an essay and it was all wrong. The information was "obscure, though incorrect." Which proves, that not all information on Wikipedia is true.(Source #5)

In recent years, Wikipedia is known for their misinformation demonstrated throughout the site due to its invalid quotes and obscurities. In Source #4, an Irish student from Dublin university posted a quote on Wikipedia which was entirely fabricated with no validity in it. Such lack of attribution, Wikipedia administrators removed the quote, but it still demostrates how a user- edited page on Wikipedia can be one of the many faults that Wikipedia has in providing misinformation to the public. In Source #3, it states how Wikipedia lacked clarity in many of its articles as the contents found in the articles were very dense. This proves that Wikipedia demonstrates that its sites are known cesspools of obscure information due to the multiple mistakes made by user created sites and dense information that doesn't show clarity whatsoever.

"The percentage of all American adults who use Wikipedia to look for information has increased from 25% in February 2007 to 42% in May 2010, a 17 percent increase" Source #1. You can see the rapid growth and use of Wikipedia, it is inevitable that the views on the content will also increase. As new generations grow more fond of Wikipedia, more and more people will become users. As more people become users, falsified information will become more available to a larger audience. "The sociology major's made-up quote... flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newpaper Web sites in Britain, Austrailia and India" Source #4. When trusted sources, like newspapers, use Wikipedia as a source, it creates another medium for misinformation to spread to the public. Wikipedia, being the widely used outlet of information as it is, relies solely on people of the internet to see its content. This changes when the news uses it for stories. This creates a whole new medium for information, true or false, to be spread.
It can be easily vandalized. Source 2 It can be hoaxed easily. Source 4

Certain sources demonstarted that misinformation on Wikipedia can spread quickly. These sources are source #2 and source #5. Source #2 is simply an article that focuses on an experiment by a University of Dublin student that actually tested how quickly a piece of misinformation on Wikipedia could spread. Source #5 is an article that placed its focus on a University professor and his outrage towards Wikipedia as well as his students for acquiring incorrect information while studying for their exams. Both sources, and their examples of misinformation spreading quickly can be explained by the idea of humans being inherently lazy creatures. In both cases, obituarist and students, rather than using an encyclopedia correctly and as a springboard for research utilize it as the research information. They chose not to check the sources of the information and actually engage in research. That is the reason why incorrect information on Wikipedia is spread quickly because numerous people choose to be lazy, and take the information for face value rather than using the encyclopedia correctly and utilize it as a springboard for "research".

on the internet anything could be believed, i could put up that Barack Obama was a racisest and the reader could believe me or not. Another source is Trust Wikipedia ? Yes, when it comes to cancer anyway by Tami Dennis, she tells the readers that "[...]content's reliability should be met with some skepticism. After all, it's created by users, not traditional 'experts' ". There is the main idea that people should realize, not everything on the internet is true.

Misinformation can spread quickly from people doing research on "exploring how quickly information is transmitted around the world" to a research papaer in a Japanese history class. In source #3 Fitzgerald used a phony quote he made up and it was "used in many blogs and several newspapers at the start or finish of their obituaries." Fitzgerald said that people "shouldnt avoid wikipedia, but that they shouldnt use information they find there if it cant be traced back to a reliable primary source."

Wikipedia is an open source based knowledge center. It is open to the general public for altercation of its contents. It wouldn't take long for a single person to go through and screw with as many documents as they wanted to.

"Wikipedia is a force" Dan Fletcher says. In the article, A Brief History Of Wikipedia, Fletcher says people who like it or loath it still use it. The website is a bi-lingual website and is used in many different countries where other websites ant be used. Wikipedia is a very well known source and therefore people will continue to use it.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because, "under pressure to produce news instantly, media outlets [are] increasingly relying on...Wikipedia" (source #4). This shows that even though the information may be incorrect, the journalists still use it in order to get their stories written on time. This error could lead to millions seeing the misinformation, spreading across the globe. Also, when students are "cramming" for an exam, they most likely will look to Wikipedia for help. This may spread quickly because a trick that one student uses will be passed on to other students, regardless of if it is misinformation or not.

Wikipedia spokesman Jay Walsh said he appreciated the Dublin student's point, and said he agreed it was "distressing so see how quickly journalists would descend on that information with out double-checking it." Althought Middlebury's history department has banned Wikipedia in citations, it has not banned its use. Department chairman Don Wyatt said a total ban on Wikipedia would have been impractical, not to mention close-minded, because wikipedia is too handy to expect students never to consult it.

Information can become inaccurate on wikipedia relatively easily. The ability to add one's personal input about a certain topic on Wikipedia is a growing problem for the rest of the users who rely on this website for their own purposes. For example, Source 2 describes how, even when it first began to indulge in its promising prominence, Wikipedia had to face a serious problem- vandalism. Many people are able to edit any page they want on Wikipedia but the "user-generated encyclopedia" has not changed its settings from allowing anybody to modify pages to allowing only a certain group of people who can be depended on providing accurate information; this allows the spread of misinformation to increasingly grow. Even if the creator of this online encyclopedia decides to ban the freedom of adding information onto its pages whenever someone chooses to do so, most of the information that people will get, in order to undeniably modify the Wikipedia pages that have been plagued by the vandalism of misinformation, are from the internet, where the infinite sources that claim to be truthful are all but just exaggerated stories or lies. In addition, Source 4 explains how one Irish student managed to fool whole nations all over the world. By posting a made up quote on Wikipedia, much less the internet, it was only a matter of time until people from different parts of the world were bound to see it. With the incredibly fast way technology works today, anything that is posted on the internet can be transmitted in seconds. These demonstrations of adding misinformation that is irrelevant to a topic or article on an international website can spread quickly like wildfire on a dry, humid day.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly, as proven by Sources #4 and #5. In Source #4, Shane Fitzgerald, a Dublin University student, "posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia" to test how our "globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news." Although the quote Fitzgerald posted on the site was fake, Wikipedia users and administrators themselves were blind to the quote's infidelity. After a month of silence, Fitzgerald decided that if he had not told the truth about his made-up quote, it "would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something I made up." This proves that misinformation can not only be considered credible in daily life, but also in widespread, international history, as suggested by Fitzgerald. In his article from The Taipei Times entitled "Wikipedia on an academic hit list," Noam Cohen affirms that misinformation can spread quickly. Cohen opens his piece by connecting the unreliabilty of Wikipedia to real life situations. In his Japanese history class, Neil Waters found that most of his students stated the same untrue statement in their exams. After investigation, Waters found that the "obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." Although Wikipedia is a great source for quick, general information, its unreliability cannot be overlooked, especially in the case of a last-minute "cramming session." The incorrect statement Waters identified in most of his students' exams came from the exact same place, showing that many students use Wikipedia as a resource, and consequently, any untrue information presented in Wikipedia can be directly spread to its users, and even indirectly spread to others. Therefore, the incidence in Waters' history class confirms that misinformation can spread quickly.

With so many users, information found on Wikipedia is easily found and spread, whether it's correct or incorrect. For example, in source 4, when discussing the fraudulent quote posted by an Irish student, the author paraphrases Fitzgerald's words and reports that "[Journalists] used the fabricated material...even though adminitrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first." In an article by Noam Cohen, it is revealed that half a dozen students got the wrong answer on a test after using Wikipedia, where "the students had picked [the incorrect information] up cramming for [teacher Neil Waters] exam." When information is as easily accessible as a Wikipedia article, it is destined to be subjected to widespread use.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because many outside sources are desperate for information so they are not careful with the information seen, and so many people use Wikipedia that the information is seen by many people. In the age of technology, news spreads fast, and everyone wants to be the first to know about it, which leads them to, "increasingly rely on internet sources-none more ubiquitous than the publicly edited Wikipedia," therefore information on Wikipedia is spread quickly(Pogatchnik). It is also because of how many people use WIkipedia. According to Pew Research center, "42% of all Americans turn to the popular collaborative encylopedia for information online," so almost half the population of America sees the information, making it easy for them to spread that information to the other 60%.

False information published on Wikipedia can go viral because often times news journalists often fail to fact-check their material: "it was distressing to see how quickly journalists would descend on that information without double-checking it" (Source 4) and that the online encyclopedia is not an error-free source: "...no one argues that Wikipedia's content is flawless" (Source 2).

unlike any other website, wikipedia is a site that is able to be changed by anyone as mentioned in article #4. i tells about a university student who changed a poem on the site and went without any detection thus showing, like in article #5, that those student who rely on wikipedia for research papers other school related assighnment are mostlikly giving and receaving false information that other people around the world have changed.

In this Information Age, the Internet is often called as the Sea of Information and has enormous influence on people's daily lives. People around the world read everything from new articles to published research papers on their phones or tablet PCs at every second. Therefore even a tiny piece of misinformation is spread around the world in an instant. To test how the media would take in misinformation posted on a Wikipedia article, Shane Fitzgerald from Dublin University placed a false quote on a Wikipedia article on Maurice Jarre. What he found was astounding. Instanly, the media, especially journalists and the news, began to use the quote on their reports. [Source #4]. The misinformation was unnoticed by some 40 million users until Fitzgerald told the media the truth. The reason this event occured is mainly because of the tendency of people to believe what is written on the Internet. They believe that Wikipedia articles have been checked by the experts before they are posted online. Second reason the misinformation can spread so quickly is that there are just so many people who use the information posted on Wikipedia. With more than 38 million users for articles in English when the articles are written in more than 270 languages [Source #2], even if the quote was online for just a few seconds, dozens or even hundreds of people would have seen that quote in that article.

Wikipedia is a tool that is used for the access of information, but being a user edited site, it can be liable to misinformation. After the death of a famous poet, many people flocked to Wikipedia to find out more about him. Seeing an opportunity in this, a fake quote was placed in the poet's entry and it, "flew straight on to dozens of blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India." (4) An important event may cause an extreme spread of misinformation if it is not caught on time by Wikipedia's editors. Situations may also occur where people need to know something in order to prepare, for example students preparing for an exam. At Middlebury College, many students, "asserted on exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan." This need for information also can contribute to the spread of misinformation.

In source 4, the narrator explains the spreading of false attribution,"even though administrators at the free online encyclpedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some jouarnalists from cutting and pasting it first"(4). One of the reasons that misinformation spread without being stopped is that there are simply more journalists spreading the word compared to the editors who are getting rid of it.

In the artricle "A Brief History of Wikipedia," Fletcher states that there were some prolems when it came to Wiki. Such as vandalism and overseeing what should and shouldn't go on the site. The accuracy of Wiki was also a problem; the Wiki resource has similar accuracy and depth to the professionally edited database. Because of these problems, misinformation can easily spread quickly and people could easily use wrong information without knowledge of it being false. In source 4, when Shane Fitzgerald posted a poetic, but fake quote on Wikipedia that French composer Maurice Jarre "supossedly" said, journalism blew it up without even knowing if the source was real or not. Fitzgerald did this as an experiment to see how fast false news could spread through the internet. His experiment worked seeming how most blogs and newspapers were using his phony quote. This clearly shows that when using Wikipedia it's almost taking a fifty/fifty chance that you could be using false information. Misinformation can spread like wildfire on the internet and this is a clear example of it.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly due to people forgetting that not all of it's information is credible. The example in Source 4 where a college student posted a fake qoute and "a full month went by and nobody noticed the editorial fruad" illustrates people's unwavering belief that all Wikipedia information is accurate. Some people no longer question the credibility of a source, and instead absentmindedly copy down what is shown. In thinking that the information given is the truth, many can learn and relay incorrect concepts. Wikipedia is "created by users, not traditional 'experts' "(Source 3). Although the site tries to be as accurate as possible, -which gains the faith of its users- the belief that everything on the site is factual makes misinformation spread rapidly.
because pretty much anyone can edit the pages

The rapid spreading of misinformation can be brought down to many things. First off the more users the more misinformation that is spread. to support this the site has over ,"13 million articles" (sourtce 2) that must be checked daily and as such more and more articles that are false slip through the fingers of the," Volunteer army of editors"(source 2) that maintain the site's accuracy. Yet anouther reason for the exponential expansion of false information is," how quickly journalists would descend on ... information without double-checking it" (source 4). As described in the source a student wanted to see how quickly false information can spread. the result ended up being the student had to anounce that he made up the quote as an expiriment ending the speading of the false quote.

Wikipedia is full of information and some of it may be incorrect like how " the Jesuits supported Shimabara Rebellion in the 17th-Century Japan" (Source 5#). Or also how a student posted a false quote to see what would happen " He said it took him less than 15 minutes to fabricate and place a quote" (Source #4). Information posted on Wikipedia can sometimes be wrong for many reason. Sometimes someone may be accidentially posting wrong information or sometimes someone may do it intentially to learn what would happen.

Incorrect information of Wikipedia spreads quickly due to the wide variety of people using the site's information. After Shan Fitzgerald posted a phony quote on the website, he was surprised to discover that many writers had added his quote on their blogs or newspapers. Many "journalists eager for a quick, pithy quote" can find this information on Wikipedia (Source #4). People read these blogs and newspapers naturally assuming that they are reliable sources and spread this information to other people. As the "first listing" (Source #5) on Google, Wikipedia is also easy to access making it tempting for many people to use as a source for information that they spread. Students can also find misleading information and use it in school reports and projects. Thus the information can spread by projects and other researches.

Misinformation spreads quickly on Wikipedia as presented by Shane Fitzgerald in source #4, who posted false information on Wikipedia and then saw how quickly many others, including newspapers, believed it. Later Fitzgerald stated that Wikipedia did its job and removed his text quickly but "it was journalists eager for a quick, pilthy quote that was the problem." This demonstrates how people use Wikipedia to obtain information quickly, sometimes they do not check their facts and share the incorrect information they find. There are students that use Wikipedia because "Wikipedia is too handy to expect students to never consult it " (source 5). This becomes an even bigger problem when larger businesses like newspapers, which people are more likely to belive because they are supposed to report "facts", also share incorrect information. With such a large network like the internet avalible incorrect information not only spreads quickly but it also is harder to earse.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can occur and spread quickly because anyone can edit it, and everyone can look at it. Source #4 is an article that tells about Shane Fitzgerald, a student at Dublin university who posted a fake quote on Wikipedia. He did it to test how well the increasingly Internet dependant media was upholding accuracy and accountability of information. Journalists and newspapers used this information, and a month went by and nobody noticed. It was not until Fitzgerald told these media outlets that the corrections began. The problem is, most consumers of these media sources do not check back for corrections. Also, many of them will tell their friends about what they heard or read. There's no doubt that there are many people who are misinformed because of Wikipedia. In Source #5, several students in a history class had the same wrong answer on an exam. It turned out that they had gotten this information from Wikipedia while studying for the test. Wikipedia has millions of users and articles. Anyone can post misinformation that millions of people will read, and in most cases, believe.

"Irish student hoaxes word's media with fake quote" was created because Shane Fitzgerald was able to sieze the oppertunity to put up a fake quote of three time Oscar winner and watch the media quickly grab what seemed to be a perfect quote right off of Wikipedia. Though Wikipedia quickly took it down a lot of journalists were more than happy to accept it as fact, and since many readers of these newspapers such as The Guardian don't question the media's sources, a lot of people would easily accept and spread the misinformation. A lot of people take the information that they read as true, just like those in Middlebury College have (Source 5) when students all had the same incorrect answer to a test question. Wikipedia is convinient for those in a rush such as journalist who have a time deadline as well as students who have to cram for their many tests so any information is taken as true and then remembered for the important task ahead. One thing simply creates a ripple effect, and misinformation on Wikipedia certainly can create large effects.

Wikipedia has been found to hold false information in its lifetime. For example, students at Middlebury College used false info on Wikipedia for Neil Waters' Japanese history class as they "had picked it up cramming for his exam." (#5) Students who had studied this topic used false information on Wikipedia to help for their exam which the students did not study for effectively. Due to this, the history branch banned Wikipedia for being cited in essays/classwork. Another example would be the false quote spread by Shane Fitzgerald to test "how the media would handle it." (#4) Journalists from the United States and Great Britain were soon found to be using the false quote in their articles with no citation whatsoever. Sites like the Guardian quickly apologized to the public and Fitzgerald, while others instead quickly scorned him for writing false information. Thus, Wikipedia can hold misinformation that could spread very quickly to anyone wanting to read its articles.

In source #4, a student from Dublin university was conducting an experiment on false information on Wikipedia; Shane Fitzgerald had posted a false quote that supposedly came from the famous conductor Maurice Jarre, on Wikipedia, testing the media's accuracy on information and accountability on their stories. A few hours after Jarre's death, Shane had posted the quote on Wikipedia and had instantly been put on dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India. This showed that the media doesn't do much research at all, and use any information they can find without tracking it's source. In source #5, Neil Waters, a professor from Middlebury College, Vermont, had realized that his students are being given false information when he read the students exams. Waters had realized that the students have been getting their information from Wikipedia, and this is because they had decided to get it from the website because they had been "cramming," or studying hard for his exam. Another problem with misinformation is the possibility of believing vandalized and diluted content. Invalid information that is posted on Wikipedia can be easily spread throughout the other screens of Wikipedia users. For example, in the article "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media with Faking Quote," written by author Shawn Pogatchnik, presents how quickly university student Shane Fitzgerald's test of making up a false quote from past French composer Maurice Jarre spread to various journalists across the Internet. Fitzgerald's test shows how many different journalists easily copied and pasted his false quote to write and spread their own articles on Jarre's mysterious new quote. Also, in "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List" written by Noam Cohen shows how quickly more than half a dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class accessed an article to cram for an exam. Wikipedia is often used as a quick go-to for students who are trying to cram for essays and finals exams such as students in Waters' class and probably many students across America. The quick click of a search button on the Internet can cause students to have easy access to articles that may contain fale information that will eventually lead students and journalists to invalid articles and essays.

While many individuals worldwide use Wikipedia, misinformation, through the medium of Wikipedia, is becoming an increasingly common trend. It is extremely simple to look up a subject on Wikipedia and to write up on the subject for a class or for some other means. While it is unlikely that most information on Wikipedia is fabricated, simply editing in false information isn't difficult. In the article, "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media with Fake Quote", by Shawn Pogatchnik of the Seattle Times. Pogatchnik reports of the social experiment that Irish student Shane Fitzgerald conducted. He made up an uncited quote that was attributed to the late Maurice Jarre. Even though the quote was uncited, dozens of blogs and newspapers worldwide had referenced this quote in their obituary articles of Jarre. A month had passed and the fabrication had not been spotted until Fitzgerald alerted the media sources. Some sources had still misattributed the quote to Jarre several weeks after Fitzgerald alerted the public. The sheer simplicity of taking a quote from a concise and popular well of information, even though the well is user-submitted and the quote had no citations of its sources proved to be too tempting for many journalists and showed the decreasing interest of firsthand sources of a subject. Another example of misinformation spread by means of Wikipedia can be seen in Noam Cohen's article in the Taipei Times, "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List." Neil Waters of Middlebury College, Vermont had seen several of his students written on exams using information that was completely incorrect. Upon further investigation, Waters discovered that Wikipedia was the source of misinformation, several of his students had used Wikipedia as a last minute cram option for their exams. As Waters had seen, convenience of sources is a reason how misinformation can be spread. It's extremely simple to apply information from Wikipedia which was found as one of the first results of an internet search, instead of looking through several pages for a source specializing in the subject. Not questioning articles of accuracy because of convenience is another reason why misinformation can easily be spread.

Source 4 and 5 illustrate how misinformation can spread quickly; obviously this happens because millions of people view articles daily but as illustrated by source 5, mistakes are quickly removed. The blame does not fall on wikipedia for spreading misinformation however; the blame should be laid on the lazy students, educators, journalists and regular people who do not check the source qoutation's at the bottom of every wikipedia page.

According to Source #4, a Dublin university student, Shane Fitzgerald, was able to post a "poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia". His fake quote was quickly published on U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia, and India. The fake quote he posted was quickly spread and no one bothered to check the accuracy of it. Source #5 shows how students from a Japanese history class at Middlebury College put their faith in Wikipedia, and were actually being fed the wrong information. Even though the information on Wikipedia was false, the students still used it. Why? Simply because they didn't know any better and they put their trust into Wikipedia. Because of this, the students began to pass around the wrong information and came up with many errors on their exams.

Because of Wikipedia's enormous volume, easy to access capability, and completely free access nature, it is easy to see why millions of people around the world use it as a source of information on various different subjects. However, Wikipedia's user-edited nature also has a problem, which is that because anyone can alter information on it, flase information can be planted or missed that leads people to false conclusions. Source #4 describes this briliantly because in that source, a student named Shane Fitzgerald intentionally posted false knowledge in order to test how the media responed and if they would factcheck it. When several blogs and media outlets started using the quote as fact, Shane stepped in and informed these outlests that he had made up the quote as an experiment. Even though the false information was brought down quickly, people had already quoted it and displayed it as fact, showing that even though the false material may be found and removed, if it is placed at a key moment in time, it can still reach millions as fact before it is resolved. This effect is evident in source #5 as well where Neil Water's Japanese history class asserted that "the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan" (Source #5) which was impossible because the Jesuits were few in number and those that existed were in hiding. In this case, the students used Wikipedian information as fact and didn't bother to corroborate their findings from Wikipedia with other sources in the world. Because of the misinformation, six students believed it and tried to pass it off as truth to their teacher in an essay. Both of these sources show that while Wikipedia has enormous stores of knowledge and a lot of people willing to expose and correct mistakes, it can't all be checked all at once and a smartly placed bit of misinformation can go down as truth to millions at a moments notice.

Wikipedia has 3 million articles in the english language, and contains more than 13 million articles in 271 different languages. (source #2) This allows people all over the globe to access the same information. Consequently, the misinformation can spread everywhere rapidly. An Irish student intentionally posted a false quote on a recently dead actress, Maurice Jarre, to see how fast the misinformation spread in the media. His results were that many publications used his quote without checking if it was false or not. (Source #4) Because people do not check the information they get off of Wikipedia, the misinformation in it spreads very quickly, even if Wikipedia takes it down after finding the fault.

Because Wikipedia is an entirely public platform, the spread and use of misinformation is highly likely. In Source #5, a teacher expresses his outrage after dozens of student papers contain false historical information. The teacher harangued Wikipedia for allowing false information to posted on its site, and took furthur action to make sure students would no longer be able to cite Wikipedia in their papers. There are too factors that played into this situation: one is that Wikipedia articles are written by public users not actual experts on the topics, and two is the fact that students are increasingly using the internet for the majority of their research needs. Because most of the site's articles are writing by everyday Joes, the risk for error is about 3.86 mistakes per article (Source # 2). The increase in student use of the internet also caused many of them to cite the source incorrectly.

Misinformation can happen due to promising pieces of information and a pressure to use it. One exmaple can be seen from a quote supposedly from the dying lips of Maurice Jarre posted onto Wikipedia. While many journalists were quick to take in the information as accurate, it turns out that the "poetic but phony quote" was created as an experiment to see how people would take it. The event at Middlebury College in Vermont is another example that also shows that promising information and pressure is a factor in how misinformation can be spread quickly. Under the stress of exams, many of Neil Waters' students turned to Wkipedia for help but found and used "obscure , though incorrect, information"(Cohen).

To begin with, when false information is entered "administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly [catch] the [article's] lack of attribution and [remove] it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first" (4). This implies that if someone ends up making a mistake on an article, then the chances are that many people would see and record it before the admins can evaluate it. The article also states that "journalists would descend on [the] information without double-checking it" (4). This shows that many journalists make the mistake of shallowly evaluating credbility because they mostly care about spreading news, not checking it.

After the death of Maurice Jarre, Fitzgerald posted a made-up quote on Wikipedia on Jarre's page. "Administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first" (#4). Many newspapers ended up containing this quote. In Middlebury College, "half a dozen students in Neil Waters' Japanese history class"(#5) had false statements on their exams. The professor found out that the students got the false information from Wikipedia and it was only "a year ago that students [started] citing Wikipedia as a source in their papers" (#5).

Another factor to the quickly spreading misinformation is that many students, not only in middle schools and high schools, but also colleges are using Wikipedia and trusting it as a valid and correct source. "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for an exam." (Source 5) This shows that anyone anywhere in the world can find incorrect information and use it for anything they want, causing it to spread all over the place.

There are several factors that relate to misinformation posted on Wikipedia and how quickly it can spiral out of control. In its earlier days, Wikipedia had to deal with issues such as "vandalism and the lack of a fixed formula for determining what should and should not be included in an encyclopedia unconstrained by physical limits" (Source 2). This made it easy for hackers to feed people the wrong facts, and to instead write about subjects that are completely bizzare. The lack of hard facts can also mislead those who wish to know the real answers. When student Shane Fitzgerald of Dublin University posted a phony quote on the page of French composer Maurice Jarre, an obituarist used that quote when writing about Jarre (Source 4). Fitzgerald's experiment, in this case, was a success, showing how journalists rely on Wikipedia and do not take the time to review their sources. These are a few of the several ways Wikipedia presents minsinformation.

Wikipedia is an easily accessible website that all users have access to and can edit publicly or use information from. Because of this information and misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread very quickly as shown in an article by The Seattle Times. An Irish student is able to bewilder the world with a quote he had written posing as a recently deceased French Composer. As an "experiment" to see how fast misinformation can be posted, this Irish student had posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia, and it was swallowed by society. Wikipedia is also shown as a source for misinformation produced by an article from The Taipei Times by Noam Cohen, where students were using misinformation that they had picked up from Wikipedia on a test and getting it wrong. This can easily happen because as students, we are faced with many tests throughout our school years and in order to study for this we turn to the Internet. The Internet provides an easy to access style that many students eagerly need and Wikipedia is a site that provides all that for students like these. Wikipedia is a source that provides mainly legitimate claims and facts, however, there are few that are not and because of this they are not recommended by many teachers. In an ever-changing society that seeks for information faster than the next guy, Wikipedia holds the key to it. Yes they arent always correct, but when searching for the key, we don't always check for if it can open the right door.

According to source #4, sometimes even journalism and the media can fall victim to misinformation on Wikipedia. In this case, journalists want to be the first on scene, and they may take shortcuts and not double-check the reliability of their facts. One of Wikipedia's biggest problems, is that audienced are sometimes given misinterpreted information, or are given pseudo-facts. Something to keep in mind though, is that most encylopedias are not one-hundred percent accuarate most of the time. The main reason that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly is that many people who use the website do not verify that the information found on Wikipedia is true. This idea can be clearly seen in Article #4, "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media with Fake Quote", in which Dublin university student Shane Fitzgerald posted a fake quote on Wikipedia that was used by many media outlets despite being removed from Wikipedia within a few hours. Once the quote was revealed to be a hoax, the reader's editor at The Guardian, one of the newespapers that posted the fake quote, stated, "The moral of this story is not that journalists should avoid Wikipedia, but that they shouldn't use information they find there if it can't be traced back to a reliable primary source." Another example of lack of outside fact checking causing misinformation from Wikipedia to spread can be seen in Article #5, "Wikipedia on an Academic Hit List". This article describes a case when a number of students in a Japanese history class at Middlebury College used the same false argument in their essay, stemming from an incorrect fact found on Wikipedia. This led to the college professor banning the citing of Wikipedia as a source, stating that it should only be used a first step to finding reliable sources. Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales agreed with this policy, stating, "They are recommending exactly what we suggested-students shouldn't be citing encyclopedias." This article also proves that Wikipedia can be a useful tool, but without fact-checking it with outside information, incorrect information can spread quickly.

In source #4, Pogatchnik explains the story of a student named Fitzgerald posting a phony quote on a composers page after the composers death. Fitzgerald was testing if media would be able to notice if this is a credible source or if they would remove it for being a fraud. The media however, through its hunger to spread what it can, 'cut and paste' the quote without checking its source. Although Wikipedia removed the quote, the media never noticed the fraud until Fitzgerald came out and explained what had happened. Supporting this, Pogatchnik states, "I am 100-percent convinced that if i hadn't come forward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something i made up. It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enough times in the media without challenge. it becomes a fact." This quote is an example on how the misinformation that was posted on Wikipedia spread and that was because of media. Another source would be source #5, written by Noam Cohen on a japanese history class professor noticing that exams that were turned in held multiple and repeated errors. The professor, Neil Waters, concludes that,"The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and the students had picked it up cramming for his exam." However, this was not a good thing. The wikipedia source gave away different information, usually incorrect, and he noticed this in the exam. Cohen writes that, "But the errors on the test last semester were the last straw," and furthermore explains Waters' determination to stop wikipidea from being a cited source on papers or exams becuase of the misinformation.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because people never go and look a primary source or another source to prove if the information is correct or not. In Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote Shawn Pogatchnik, reports that a student from Dublin university named Shane Fitzgerald, posted a quote of his own on Maurice Jarre after hours of his death. Fitzgerald conducted a little experiment to see how gualible people are and see if people would use Wikipedia as source. It seemed like Fitzgerald wanted to prove a point that everything on Wikipedia is not accurate or trust worthy. In Wikipedia On An Academic Hit List Noam Cohen, explains how Middlebury College banned of quoting or citing Wikipedian on their exams because wikipedia's information was inaccurate making students fail their exams.

Often times we also find misleading information online due to Wikipedia's allowance of public posting. Japanese history teacher Neil Waters figured this out when half a dozen of his students stated a wrong answer on their exams. He found the fault to be where they got their information. "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia," (5) and the students picked it up while studying the night before. Another instance when public posting effected people was when a Dublin university student posted a quote just to see if anyone would fall for it. Less than 15 minutes was the time it took for Shane Fitzgerald to come up with a fake quote for the death of Maurice Jarre. But no one seemed to notice it was fake even after a month, and that's when he reached out to media outlets via e-mail and began correcting others. Fitzgerald was, "really shocked at the results from the experiment," he didn't know it would reach this high. (4)

Shane Fitzgerald, a 22 year-old Dublin student, wrote a quote claiming to be Maurice Jarre's on his wikipedia page soon after his death. Fitzgerald claimed to do this as a test. He wanted to see if it would be noticed as fraud or not. The quote went unnoticed, and was copy and pasted on to other web pages until Fitzgerald came out about the error. So many journalists just copied the information without checking if there was an accurate source to back the quote up. This shows that false information can spread very quickly.

Wikipedia can hold and spread misinformation due to the way that it was created and is currently run. To protect against vandalisma and misinformation being added to the page Wikipedia has "a volunteer army of editors" who make sure that nothing incorrect gets added (Source #2). However, this volunteer army may take some time to catch every mistake in all 1 million or more articles. There is a log created, but oftentimes the mistakes aren't caught quick enough. In the incident described in Source #4, the encyclopedia caught and removed the fake quote, "but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first" (Source #4). Since people are one Wikipedia all the time, any misinformation not caught immediately can be snagged by someone and used as correct if not found elsewhere.

Although wikipedia can be credible most of the time, there are moments where misinformation can be posted. Even though these mishaps are usually fixed within minutes or hours it can sometimes have a big affect. Such as Shane Fitzgerald posting a fake poetic quote on the page of Maurice Jarre hours after the french composers death. Where many Journalists and Blogs began to put in thier obituraries. Fitzgerlad said " I am 100 percent convinced that if I hadn't come foward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said instead of something I made up." "It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enough time in the media without challenge, it becomes fact." - "Irish Student Hoaxes World's Media With Fake Quote" by The Seattle Times. A study shown by Nature found "that Wikipedia's science entiries came close to matching the Encyclopedia Britannica's in terms of accuracy-with 2.92 mistakes per article for Britannica and 3.86 for Wikipedia- no one argues that Wikipedias content is flawless." This also shows that although that wikipedia can be a credible source most of the time, it is not always right.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread rapidly. Just take for example, Shane Fitzgerald, for when he posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia about a recently dead composer, it "flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia, and India." (Source 4). Journalists and other individuals that thrive to have the story first or get their article out on time rush to internet sources to fufill that request. Even Wales said "If they put out a statement not to read Wikipedia at all, I would be laughing. They might as well say don't listen to rock 'n' roll either. (Source 5). With students and adults frequently using Wikipedia for their studies and other purposes, the misinformation posted can spread quickly.

Misinformation on Wikipedia spreads simply because of careless research by the users of the online encyclopedia. As in source #4, a student can post any information that they wish to post, such as a fake quote by a recently diseased celebrity. This information spread throughout the media because the users of Wikipedia were lazy and careless. It is not very hard to go on a search engine and search for a quote. When the quote appeared nowhere but the Wikipedia article, a red flag should have gone off. Also, the journalists who misused this information should have seen that the quote was not cited and therefore was not reliable. Students are another group prone to misuse of the information on Wikipedia. Students want a quick, easy way to get the research that they need for a paper or an exam. Wikipedia is the solution. However, in that panicked, rushed state, students are often too careless to check the information that they find, or don't even notice that the information is not cited. The users of this famous online encyclopedia are the ones to blame for the misuse of the information presented online.

In the beggining, Wikipedia was dealing with a lot of different problems, one of them being vandalism. Source # 2 explains just why this what happening and how Wikipedia has worked to solve this problem. "...Amoung them were vandalism and the lack of a fixed formula for determining what should and shouldn't be included in an encyclopedia unconstrained by physical limitations. The emerging community included a volunteer army of editors, who helped to keep the content aligned with Wikipedia's rules..." The poor guidelines set by Wikipedia when it first came out was a big reason as to why the sources and information on the website were invalid. This has since been changed. Source # 4 gave a good example of just how fast false information can spread because of Wikipedia by telling the story of a boy named Shane Fitzgerald who made up a quote who he claimed was said by Maurice Jarre hours after the French composer's death. This quote made its way to dozens of blogs and newspaper Web sites in the U.S., Britain, Australia, and India. Fitzgerald said, "The used fabricated material even though administrators at the free online encyclopedia quickly caught the quote's lack of attribution and removed it, but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first." Months had gone on and yet nobody noticed the false information untl Fitzgerald had told several media outlets. Fitzgerald concluded by stating, "I am 100-percent convinced that if I hadn't come forward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, instead of something I made up. It would have become another example where, once anything is printed enough times in the media without challenge, it becomes fact."

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. In source #4, an article titled 'Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote' written by Shawn Pogatchnik, Pogatchnik explains how society's desire for instant news allows many to be gullible and believe anything on the internet. In the article, Pogatchnik writes, "When Dublin university student Shane Fitzgerald posted a poetic but phony quote on Wikipedia, he said he was testing how our globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news. His report card: Wikipedia passed. Journalism flunked." Pogatchnik goes on to add..."The sociology major's made up quote flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Austrailia and India." Here, the author of source #4 demonstrates how rapidly, and how far away, false information can spread. Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can also spread quickly due to the fact that it has a very wide audience. Source #5, titled 'Wikipedia on an academic hit list' written by Noam Cohen states that, "Indeed, the English-language version of the Web site had an estimated 38 million users in the US in December, and can be hard to avoid while on the Internet." Because so many people have access to and are able to see false information on Wikipedia, this information spreads at a much higher rate.

Wikipedia is known to be reliable but it is also known to provide other with misinformation. In "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote" (source #4), the author Shawn Pogatchnik tells a story of a Dublin university student posted a fake quote on wikipedia. Shawn was testing how quick Wikipedia was to find the inaccuracy in this quote. Misinformation can spread quickly on wikipedia because as soon as it is online people are quick to copy and paste this information and there are thousands of articles administrators have to check. By the time an administrator checked the article it would be late and they might not even have found the mistake. Shawn had to email the organization after a month went by without his fake quote being changed. This is one example of how misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. Source #5 also provides an accurate example of how quickly misinformation can spread on Wikipedia. In "Wikipedia on an academic hit list" A professor of Middlebury College found an error in students' papers regarding the Shimabara Rebellion in Japan. He then realized that the source of this error was from Wikipedia. This innacurate information had been on Wikipedia long enough for students to use it in their papers and recieve a bad grade due to the wrong information. These sources support the arguement that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly.

Information put on Wikipedia that is misguided happens because the site allows anyone to edit or add content to a page. Even if Wikipedia deleted the addition to the page; it was still out circlling around the worlds' press. Journalists or anyone that sees something aren't thinking of looking for a realiable source. This is proven from the journalists that used Fitzgeralds' false quote about Maurice Jarre or people that surf the web looking for a certain topic because;In source 5 it states, Wikipedia is the first entry shown on websites like Google making it nearly impossible to avoid. So if Wikipedia is part of the first websites shown then anyone viewing the information can circulate the subject around like it's noothing. The Wikipedia system has about 1,500 volunteer administrators that are trained to spot new additions made on pages. The administrators remove any bogus, fabricated, or biased additions in a relatively fast time. Misinformation can spread quickly because they might have accuracy problems.

Source #2 explains that because there is no limitations to what can be posted it is easy to put up false information. Wikipedia is "unconstrained by physical limitations." Anyone can post anything. Even with a large team of editors the site has grown so large that it is difficult to control information quickly. Source #4 talks one case where false information spread quickly. This was not due to Wikipedia's failure to edit. The false information was taken down within the hour. Rather, the infomation spread because so many people, including journalists, were willing to take the information straight from wikipedia without checking it first. The reason misinformation can spread so quickly is because it has some problems making it not always reliable, and people trust it as reliable.

Misinformation is a result of the structure of the website. An indivdual has the ability to edit the work in whatever way they desire, leading to inaccurate additions within the body of work. Source 2 explains how Wikipedia has a "lack of a fixed formula for determining what should and shouldn't be included in an encyclopedia unconstrained by physical limitations." Additionally, the articles written within Wikipedia are "created by users, not traditional experts." (Source 3) The articles do not have the most informed or educated authors, which could lead to the inclusion of biased, inaccurate, or unrelated information about the topic.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because according to source number 3, wikipedia pages are created by users, not "experts". in source number 4, it explains how a sociology major made up a quote and added it to the wiki page of Maurice Jarre after his death on march 28th. The quote went straight to dozens of U.S blogs and newspaper sites in Britain, Australia, and India. After a month went by, nobody noticed that it was fake. If he didnt come forward, he was 100% sure that the quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre really said.

It is not unheard of that misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly. This can be caused both by users not following-up out of desperation and/or blind acceptance. For example, in Neil Waters' Japanese history class at Middlebury College, multiple students in the class used the same "obscure, though incorrect, information" on their exams. Waters was able to trace the information back to Wikipedia and conclude that the students were desperate for quick study materials while cramming (Cohen). In the same light, Source #4 reports on an experiment preformed by an Irish student on how quickly false information on Wikipedia spreads. In response to his experiment's astonishing, alarming results, the student, Shane Fitzgerald, says, "If anything...he expected newspapers to avoid his quote because it had no link to a source-and even might trigger alarms as 'too good to be true.' But many blogs and several newspapers used the quotes at the start or finish of their obituaries" (Pogatchnik). Both these examples are because anyone can edit the information on Wikipedia at any time. While there are notifications that are sent to the Wikipedia staff so they can validate the updates, there are many more updates than staff members. This shows how easily misinformation can spread and how little effect the Wikipedia editing staff has on the public information.

Once information is on the internet, in this day and age it is accessable to anyone. In the case of Wikipedia once their information is out there, there is a slim chance they can take it back before it has fallen into the hands of another. As source 1 leads with " 42% of all Americans turn to the popular collavorative encyclopedia for information online..." with almost half of Americans turning to the internet information, whether it be true or false travels quiclkly. In addition to that although sites such as Wikipedia say they monitor false edits they cannot catch them all. In source 4 a student at Dublin Universtiy posted false information on Wikipedia to "test how our globalized increasingly Internet-dependen media was upholding accuracy and accountability in the age of instant news." His false information was not cought by the many systems put in place specifically to do so and he goes on to say that "If I hadn't cme forward, that quote would have gone down in history as something Maurice Jarre said, insted of something I made up...'

Even though Wikipedia keeps records of every entry and edit to articles, there are still several errors that the editors aren't able to fix. "If anything, Fitzgerald said, he expected newspapers to avoid his quote because it had no link to a source--- and even might trigger alarms as "too good to be true." Then several obituarist used the quote in an obituary, without checking to see if Jarre actually said it. This is misinformation that is spreading to anyone who reads the obituary. The obituarist didn't check to see if the information was correct, and now it's spreading. Another source that demonstrates misinformation spreading quickly is source #5. In this source, students use false information from Wikipedia for answers on a test. The information the students got was that "the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in 17th-century Japan." This information is incorrect. The professor knew that the correct information they needed was that there were very few Jesuits in Japan. Although the creators of Wikipedia make it a top priority to have reliable, truthful information on their website, sometimes false information does slip through the cracks and can have huge effects. This can be seen in the example ofNeil Waters' Japanese history class at Middlebury College, Vermont (Source 5). Many of his student had a skewed perspective on the Shimabara Rebellion in the 17th-century because most of his students had used Wikipedia is cram for the exam they had to take, which had incorrect information in it. Some article from Wikipedia may also be biassed or more well-written than others, such as in the case of "the site's list of Star Wars creatures totals more than 15,000 words, while the entire entry on World War II has just 10,000." It may not be a reliable source in schools because it may not have reliable information.

Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread quickly for two reasons. The first is that almost anybody can edit the articles posted on Wikipedia. Dan Fletcher of TIME magazine, said that "as [Wikipedia] grew, vandalization and dilution of the encyclopedia's content became more difficult to address (Source #2)." The second reason why misinformation spreads so quickly on Wikipedia, is that media outlets and journalists are using the information on Wikipedia without double-checking their information. An Irish student named Shane Fitzgerald fabricated a quote from Maurice Jarre and put it on Wikipedia right after Jarre's death. Fitzgerald then found that a number of news outlets were using the fictional quote in thier articles. He claims that know one would've found out if he never notified anyone about it (Source #4).

Misinformation on wikipedia can spread quickly because a lot of journalists, immediately get information mostly from the internet without even checking the original source. Irish student Shane Fitzgerald posted a fake quote on wikipedia for a French composer named Maurice Jarre that passed away recently, and many journalists used the same made up quote in many U.S blogs and newspaper articles, before wikipedia had the chance to even remove it. (Source 4.) This show how fast wrong information can get across. Another instance was a few students at Middlebury college,Vermont in a history class. A lot of them were using wikipedia as a resource, and they incorrectly responded on their exams that the "Jesuits supported the Smabara Rebellion." The professor immediately noticed that there was something wrong with that information and found out the students had been using incorrect information from wikipedia. (Source 5.) A big portion of that history class using wikipedia was reading the same wrong information.

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because of all the people using the internet. An example of such an incident is the hoax done by an Irish student. After the student, Shane Fitzgerald, posted a fake quote on the Wikipedia page of a French composer soon after her death, it went viral. Even though Wikipedia quickly found the quote and revomed it, the quote was still out there in the news. After the media had failed to see that the quote was a phony, Shane sent them an e-mail, and the media hurried to begin the corrections. (Source #4) Another example of this is when students use Wikipedia to write papers. There is always the chance of your information being wrong. This happened to Neil Waters when he was over looking a test his students had done. He searched for the source of the misimformation and soon found it. It turned out that many of the students had used Wikipedia when they where studing and had all read the same misimformation. Neil decided that it was time to put a foot down. He would no longer let students site Wikipedia on papers or use it, and sites like it, as an escape for errors. The co-founder of Wikipedia said that he didn't think it was a negative thing. He said that students shouldn't site Wikipedia or sites like it and to double check their information. (Source #5)
Wikipedia's articles are submitted by writers who very often include their opinions or versions of information that can be misleading. No one argues that Wikipedia's content is flawless (Source#2).

Misinformation posted on Wikipedia can spread quickly because users are typically in a rush to find answers or information. For example, in his article, "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote," Shawn Pogatchnik discusses how as and experiment, a student was able to spread false information about a deceased composer by posting it on Wikipedia soon after the composer's death. The experiment was designed to test the student's hypothesis that, "...under pressure to produce news instantly, media outlets were increasingly relying on Internet sources--none more ubiquitous than the publicly edited Wikipedia." This proved to be true as the false information was published by hasty journalists in newspapers and blogs. Another example of this can be found in, "Wikipedia on an academic hit list," by Noam Cohen. Cohen describes how students in a hurry to find information to study for their exam led them to trusting false information on Wikipedia. he says, "The obscure, though incorrect, information was from Wikipedia, the collaborative online encyclopedia, and teh students had picked it up cramming for his exam." Because the students were in such a rush to study, they trusted false information.

Misinformation on Wikipedia can spread very rapidly. In source four, a student at Dublin University posted a false quote that Maurice Jarre had suppossedly said. He posted this false information to test how the "globalized, increasingly Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountability in an age of instant news." As he was quick to find out, many news reporters and the media got a hold of it and Fitzgerald was not treated very well after he told the truth. In source five, the spreading of misinformation is also demonstrated. A history class used information from a Wikipedia page in their projects. Unfortunately, some of this information was incorrect. Professors were noticing that the students were citing Wikipedia as a source for about a year. Whenever the students were confronted about the citation as well as the information, the students said they had the "permission to do it in highschool." These professors suggested that the students should not use any information from Wikipedia or other encyclopedias to prevent the spread of misinfomation.

Information posted onto Wikipedia can be spread quickly, just as deminstrated in article #3 with Fitzgeralds experiment. In his experiment his made up quote "flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Wev sites in Britain, Australia and India." Also as shown in article #1 many users use Wikipedia for reasurch, including journalists.

Along with all of Wikipedia's conducive traits, it does have some draw backs. Anyone can contribute information, a nonscholar or scholar alike, making it a very large task to weed out the poorly cited, false information from the truthful. Though a tast force of 100's is assigned to correcting and deleting biased, false information, a few mistakes can slip by. As exampled in "Wikipedia on an academic hit list", a college class was able to prove a mistake in the writings of an article about the Shimabara Rebellion. Though the students knew better, a learning, oblivious user would have no idea about the misinformation. This is a faulty detail to Wikipedia and user-discretion must then be applied heavily. Along with misinformation that can easily be proved wrong, often details,quotes and other easy mishandeled information can be put up by the writers of Wikipedia. Shane Fitzgerald proved this when he made up a quote on a newly desist composer (source 4). Though Wikipedia soon removed the information, there was enough time for people to read it and believe its invalidty. This creates a whole different problem because a twist in information can be left forever and become a part of history even if it was completely false to begin with. The fact that in both situations the spread of misinformation was very fast or not even caught is a major problem with Wikipedia and its use.

Wikipedia has become a go-to source of information for students writing a research paper to journalists and columnists creating a news article. When looking into the influence of the internet on media reports, Irish student Shane Fitzgerald found "a golden opportunity" to expose the too-easily fooled media reporters for their lack of adequate research (4). The death of a famous composer led the student to enter a made-up quote onto the composer's biographical Wikipedia article (4). The flood of media flocking to online sources to quickly come up with an article on the compser's death was too easily tricked by the insertion of false information, and they quickly proceeded to report the quote as one of the late composer's very own (4). Misinformation stemming from a rush to make the day's paper is not the only source of false reporting. Students in a Japenese history college course reported on an event in history that never actually occurred (5). The late cram sessions that the students consulted Wikipedia in resulted in students learning false information (5). This occurs due to the students waiting until the last minute to prepare and rushing to learn information that should be verified with other information.
