On a site like Wikipedia, where its content is derived from its users and not the traditional 'expert', it is obvious that not every article will be viewed without skepticisim. With the thousand (plus) users Wikipedia has adopted, backed by the lack of revision upon publishing - viewers are bound to run into some mistakes. In the article, 'Irish Student Hoazes World's Media with Fake Quote', Shawn Pogatchnik reveals how misinformation can be spread instantly across the world in a short amount of time due to how advanced technology has become.

In Source 4, a student from Dublin University made up a quote that everyone around the world thought was real and put it up on Wikipedia. So, it was a shock to everyone that the quote wasn't even real. In Source 5, It explains how a rising number of college students are using Wikipedia as a source and shouldn't be because of the editors aren't professionals.

As we all know, information on a popluar topic spreads like a rumor. One College student though, decided to put that to the test. In source four, Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote. Shane Fitzgerald posted a quote that was very poetic but phony at the same time on Wikipedia to test on medias upholding accuracy and accountability. In short terms, Wikipedia passed and Journalism failed. After the quote, "One could say life itself has been one long soundtrack, Music was my life, music brought me to life, and music is how i will be remembered long after I leave this life. When I die there will be a final waltz playing in my head that only I can hear", was posted it was immediatly taken down but it was up there long enough for Journalist to see and put it in there entree. Weeks later Shane told all the newspaper writers and Journalist who used his quote what he did. To this day only one publication has admitted to this flaw. In source five it tells us how students failed a test because they used wikipedia as a source. Neil Waters couldnt figure it out on why half his class had put the same wrong answers to his test, finally he realized why exactly that happened. He found out that they all used Wikipedia as a source. Because of this mishap they decided to ban using Wikipedia as a source at Middlebury College.

In Source #4, Shane Fitzgerald added a fake quote to Maurice Jarre's Wikipedia page. Several journalists have used the quote before Wikipedia removed it. Most people will believe anything they read, and they will take false information and use it in their papers. They also might be quickly looking for information and just write down the first thing that pops out at them. Fitzgerald expected newspapers to avoid the quote because it had no link to a source, but many blogs and newspapers used the quote in their obituaries for Maurice Jarre. In Source #5, six students in a Japanese history class stated in their exams that Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion. In reality, the Jesuits had no interest in aiding a revolution. Students had gone onto Wikipedia to cram last-minute for the exam.

Although the quote did get deleted, many journalists and writers already found it, and began to use it in their writings and obituaries for the passed music composer. In Source #5, Wikipedia on an academic hit list by Noam Cohen, he tells us how students rely on Wikipedia for information, although the information may be false. Once one student finds the answer to their question on Wikipedia, other students will. For example the students in Neil Waters Japanese history class at Middlebury College, Vermont all put on their exams that the Jesuits supported the Shimabara Rebellion in the 17th-century when in fact they did not, but found their answer on Wikipedia, which was wrong.

Source#2 is full of information that says that Wikipedia is not useful. It even states, "Sanger himslef left Wikipedia in 2002 over questions about the legitimacy of the project's entries"(2). Since Wikipedia is an encyclopedia, it is forever changing to fit the needs of the world. But when the sources are changed, they're not always credible. Jay Walsh in source 4, agreed with Fitzgerald's point that journalists don't double check the credibility of information, but they shouldn't hae to if Wikipedia is as accurate as it seems at the surface. In tems of accuracy in source 2, The Encyclopedia Briannica's contains 2.92 mistakes per article and Wikipedia contains 3.86 mistakes per article.That study was done in 2005, today in this world where 3 million articles hae been published in 271 different languages, there will be mistakes that won't be caught.

Shane Fitzgerald from the University of Dublin created an experiment to test how "globalized, increasing Internet-dependent media was upholding accuracy and accountabilty in an age of instant news" (source#4). Fitzgerald's experiment not only proved how journalist weren't checking for credibility on things said on the intrnet, but he also showed how easy it is to put something on the media and how easily people will for it and belive it."The sociology major's made-up quote-which he added to Wikipedia page of Maurice Jarre hours after the French composer's death March 28-flew staright on to dozen of U.S blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India" (Source #4). Its obvious how quickly information spreads on Wikipedia. Fitzgerald's exerpiment showed how easily things can go unfiltered and how people wont question it. Perhaps thats why Neil Waters, the Japanese history class professor at Middlebury College that "Wikipedia could not be cited in papers or exams" (Source #5). Wikipedias credibiltiy is questionable because of Fitzgerald's experiment and the many errors found after his test was carried out.

Everyone is always trying to find the fastest way to get information, and for many people that includes Google. When something is typed into Googles search engine, due to the diversity of many commonly 'googled' subjects Google tends to " give the Wikipedia entry first listing."(5). Wikipedia has well over a million pages and among those are biographies of influential people, and because anyone can add information to the Wikipedia website not everything found on there is true, as many newpapers and obiturists found out when composer Maurice Jarre died. Many papers quoted a fake made-up line from Jarre's Wiki-page and when the student who cleaverly thought of this mass media test came out with the truth of the fraud- many writers were embarassed and only one came out admitting it's mistake."The sociology major's made-up quote... flew straight on to dozens of U.S. blogs and newspaper Web sites in Britain, Australia and India."(4)

Despite its steady stream of volunteer editors that monitor the authencity and rightousness of material in these articles, some things can go unnoticed and cause havok on unsuspecting victim. Even the media has been trapped into this, as seen in Source # 4, sociology student Shane Fitzgerald managed to post a fake quote supposedly uttered by Maurice Jarr. It is expected that journalist know enough not to publish material without through research, but this quote managed to appear in articles several days later. This demonstrates the blind trust given to a website even when knowing of its shortcomings. A similar case occured in a Japanese History calss when students asserted on their exams that Jesuits played a major role in the Shimbara rebellion , even though this was completely false. As a result, wikipedia is banned from being cited in formal papers but not banned entirely.

Middlebury professor Thomas Beyer said, "I guess I am not terribly impressed by anyone citing an encyclopedia as a referance point, but i am not against using it as a starting point." With that said, any information that is used from the site should be further examined by checking the sources that they came from. Information on Wikipedia, and on the internet in general, has the potential to spread at alarming rates. There are countless examples of these memes and of misinformation in particular spreading throughout the public, Source #4 mentions a situation that arose when a university student in Dublin posted a fake quote on Wikipedia on Maurice Jarre's page, immediately after the famous musician died, in order to test the media in regards to its accuracy. The quote was tailor-made for obituaries, and journalists jumped at the opportunity to use such a perfect line. The quote was widely claimed as being something Jarre actually said, and despite the facts that there was no primary source to back it up, and that administrators caught and removed the quote immediately, the damage had been done. The student called major news instutions and explained that the quote was a fake. Source #4 shows that certain people might use Wikipedia as a cop-out; it is a slough of easily available information that they do not have to put any real work in to access. Many use Wikipedia for this reason. Source #5 is a news story about a class of students enrolled in a Japanese history class at Middlebury College in Vermont. It explains a situation in which a number of students gave incorrect information on a test after using information obtained on Wikipedia to study. The frequency of this mistake was noticed, and when asked about why they used Wikipedia as a reliable source, the students stated that their high-school teachers had allowed it. This shows that Wikipedia is being widely accepted as a source that is accurate, adn those who use Wikipedia take the information presented there as the truth.

There are people who like to vadalise the website. There are also the lack of a fixed formula for determining what should and shouldn't be included. The site has a software where it keeps a log of every modification to every pagem and this tracking system has been used to bust people.

It may not always be true, and people would more often than not think that it was correct information. After posting a fake quote after the death of Jarre, it caught like a wild fire to other blogs, websites, and newspapers, stated in Source #4. People believe, most of the time, what they read online. When no one is challenging the information to check its accuracy, it can go down as a fact when printed many times.

The spread of misinformation that comes from Wikipedia comes not from Wikipedia being unreliable -- It can be -- but from the eagerness of users to use that information for their advantages. Source #4 recaps a misinformation crisis plotted by Shane Fitzgerald. Later, after studying the event of media sources citing misinformation, Shane found that "under pressure to produce news instantly, media outlets were increasingly relying on internet sources." This goes to show that a lot of the time, media outlets want to cite whats there already. Whats easiet to attain. What may be wrong in information. In addition, professor Waters at Middlebury College argues that students should not be citing Wikipedia for the reason of spreading misinformation. "But the errors on the test last semester were the last straw." The mis-citing of sources should not spread quickly which is why Waters suggest that a "total ban on Wikipedia would have been impractical, not to mention close-minded, because Wikipedia is too handy to expect students never consult it.

Misinformation spreads quickly no matter what situation one is in, but the internet has made it much easier and faster. Wikipedia has had a lot of criticism for this rapid spreading of false information. This could happen for a number of reasons. "Irish student hoaxes world's media with fake quote" explains how Wikipedia removed this false information, "but not quickly enough to keep some journalists from cutting and pasting it first." Because people didn't double-check information, a fake quote spread very quickly to other types of journalism. This wasn't necessarily Wikipedia's fault though, considering that they removed the information; the reason it was spread was due to journalists' lack of research. "Wikipedia, Past and Present" also considers reasons for quickly spreading information. Between 2007 and 2010, Wikipedia users increased from 25% to 42%. So, if the number of people using and spreading information from Wikipedia is increasing, the misinformation increases as well.
